text: hundreds of animals at London Zoo from
the tree frogs to Lions are being
measured as part of the annual weigh-in
the sizes and weights of the creatures
are recorded by their keepers so they
can monitor their health and well-being
this report is from Tim Ullman when
you're weighing someone this is not the
sort of thing that usually happens the
squirrel monkeys of London Zoo a little
reluctant to cooperate every year around
200 animals get put on the scales these
baby penguins a little more docile but
not all the zoo's inhabitants are is
willing to play ball some are definitely
less cooperative and it's not even about
being this cooperative sometimes some of
them think it's a game so some of them
would try Mike's particular and young
animals are very inquisitive when you go
in with them and I think it's a game and
they're more interested in pecking at
the scales looking at the the gloves
that are keepers wearing or running off
with some of the food and not going on
the scales it's also yeah it can be a
real challenge it's not just weight
other vital statistics are of interest
to a giant ruler being used to measure
the height of these lions with a sack of
meat encouraging them to stand on their
hind legs to get the most accurate
figures all this information helps the
zoo monitor the animals health and
well-being the information that is then
shared with other zoos around the world
from the smallest to the largest
every animal takes part whether they
want to or not
Tim almond BBC News
